segments.text: My name is Stephanie Middleton, and I am a student at Texas A&M University.
And today, November 19, 1983, I am interviewing Mr. David Pomeroy, Jr., a fourth-generation descendant of a Pasadena founder.
He is legal consultant for Pomeroy Drilling and the former president of the Pasadena Historical Society.
The Pomeroy family has had a tremendous impact on the growth and progress of Pasadena.
Mr. Pomeroy, let me start off by asking you a little background history.
When did the Pomeroy family first move to Pasadena and why did they decide to settle in Pasadena?
Pomeroy's came to Pasadena shortly after the beginning of 1901.
They had been living in Galveston in 1900 and were
caught in the great Galveston storm in September 1900 where over 7,000 people were killed in Galveston alone.
When they woke up the next day after the storm, the hurricane had hit, they looked and they could see where they had gone from Mexico.
The day before, there had been about 12 blocks of houses between them and the bay.
So they decided they were a little too close to the water and started to move back inland.
Now, they had lived in Brenham.
and had started the dairy there in the early 1890s.
So they decided, well, let's go back to Brennan.
That's a nice community we know and we're aware of.
They had stopped in Hitchcock because in-laws had been killed during the war, during the hurricane.
And they needed to tidy up the business there and to send the survivors up north to be with other relatives.
And after they'd tidied up there, then my great-grandfather, Edward Payson, probably put my great-grandmother on the train along
with the cattle that survived in the old dairy and sent them on to Brennan
like Payson and his son, John Pomboy, got in a wagon and started heading towards Brennan.
They stopped in the Pasadena area to help a farmer mend some fences and to hand-dig a waterway, which Payson had become so proficient at in the last 10 years and had some sort of reputation.
They decided, this is far enough inland, the grass is green enough, I think we're going to settle here, so he set off a telegram and had Anna return with the cows and be settled in Pasadena.
the place that we're now talking from, and we purchased in April of 1901.
It was the first piece of property, and this is my office.
We're still here.
When your family first settled in Pasadena, what was the town like, and did your family have a major role in the community?
Well, in 1901, there was a debate as to how many people were in Pasadena.
Part of the debate is, what was Pasadena?
If you look at Pasadena today, it includes what previously was five different communities, all half a day's journey from each other almost by wagon.
In the area that we are right now, the old section of downtown Pasadena, there was either six or 16 families.
I suspect there was something like, my grandfather took something over here, the sixth family in Pasadena.
I think he could probably see five other houses.
So from here, there were five other houses within view.
A little bit to the west of us, there were probably five or six houses over there.
East of us, there's a couple more houses that way.
All told, 16 was the largest number of people that claimed to have been in the general area in 1901.
By 1901, the area was all perfect.
All the trees you see today were planted by the people that came here.
The streets were, I would say, the original plat, which encompasses now
maybe 15, 20% of what the community is in size, you would have only a handful of streets.
Main Street was laid out.
It was a graded dirt street.
The Port Road, which is now Texas Highway 225, was a dirt road.
We had a railroad track through town and Shaver and Pitts.
And that's about all the streets at one time at a time.
We have one more, which is Shaw.
then called Fit Street.
The orientation of the community was around the railroad track.
The area didn't open up until the railroads came in through the area.
Let me say, as far as the Home Roy's role in the community, in the early days in particular,
There were several of the earlier families that played a significant role and carried the community.
In those days, you couldn't hire someone else to do it.
There wasn't someone else to do the job.
You had to do the job yourself.
They got very strong about schools.
So everyone initially took turns being either on the school board or carrying out the functions of the school board.
And as far as churches, you just didn't passively attend churches.
There were no churches.
You either started a church, or you sped off from a church, or you were heathen and you didn't want to be a heathen.
But there were some major families, and I like to consider them sort of family groupings.
The Pomeroy's were related by marriage to the McMasters and the Williams.
Now, the Williams came earlier.
They came in 1893 or 94, just forms.
Pomerose came in 1901, and McMaster's came in 1912.
But McMaster girls married Williams and farmers of Pomerose.
So we participated in many things together.
The same thing happened for the Parks family.
The Parks family came in 1901, later in the year, or 1902, pardon me.
And they married with the
the Blakesways and the Atkinsons and the Fortwoods and the Jacksons, and they sort of as a group formed another nucleus.
Now, I might point out, I'm sure I'll mention it more often, the community in the early days after the churches were initially founded was broken into, again, two groups.
There was the Baptist and there was the Methodist.
The Pomeranians were the Baptist and the Parks were the Methodist.
It just sort of worked out that way.
You had a couple of others.
You had the Oscar Cruz group, which is Swedish immigrants that settled out off of Ritchie Street, and they had a settlement out there.
They were very influential in the school districts, so they had a huge contribution there.
And there was Mr. A.R.
Cruz and his family.
He was a businessman.
He had the first bus company in town, the first insurance company in town, the first plumbing company in town, the first drive-in in town.
And it was all the same goal.
It's just different services, whatever you needed.
That's the way they were.
Everybody just, whatever you needed, someone came up with it.
The Pomeroy's, like most of the earlier basic families in the community, or the two or three major families, got involved.
When they came to town, there was no church.
And there was a halo to call about it.
a denominational group that was meeting in an adjoining city.
An adjoining city is Deepwater, which is now part of Pasadena, but it's about three miles from here.
So that was a Sunday morning, got up early to get on some gondola in Deepwater and came back.
So they moved the church to Pasadena, or at least they moved it to Pasadena.
And my great-grandfather, Payson Pomeroy, and his wife, Anna, were original charter members.
First Baptist Church.
There were 17 charter members.
The Williams were also charter members.
The McMaster's weren't here yet since this is 1901.
School board, my great-grandfather was an early school board member, served for several years until his death in 1906.
After that,
My grandfather was like 17 at the time, and when he got into his mid-20s, then he too got on the school board and served, I believe, some 17 years.
So they got involved in what needed to be done.
The city needed water service.
This is on in the 30s, 20s, partly.

And the Palmers were water well drillers, so they went and drilled a city water well and ran pipes to all the houses that needed and had the franchise to serve water before the town became incorporated.
They sold it to the city.
That's the beginnings of the water department we have now.
So we were involved in most everything that was going on.
Your grandfather, John Edward Pomeroy, Sr., had a great impact on Pasadena's progress.
What were some of his contributions?
Well, John, when he came to Pasadena, was 12 years old.
When his father died in 1906, he had to assume responsibility for the family.
At the time, we had a dairy and some farming, as most everybody else here had a little strawberry patch out back, or figs, or cantaloupes, or satsuma oranges, a whole host of crops.
And they were, everybody was farming 10 to,
to 20 acres is the size of the farms.
And John was involved with that.
As he grew a little bit older and solved his basic problem of earning a living for his mother and himself, then he began to get involved in the community.
He married a schoolteacher.
And so he became very interested in the school system.
Grandmother used to always have a room available for school teaching.
They would hire a teacher and they would only hire him for a session at a time.
They invariably would either room with the Pomeroy's or the Parks or maybe the Cruzes, whoever had an extra room, but we always had a room.
In fact, I sort of laughed because as my grandfather had children, they ran out of rooms to rent, so my great-grandmother built a house next door so she could continue to rent rooms out.
And that's where my uncle met his wife.
and several other people in the community met their wives.
So he got involved.
He was on the school board.
He was a member of the school board when they decided to establish a high school.
He was on the school board when they decided to establish a junior high school.
And there were some times in there he said that everybody was mad at him because he wanted to buy a lot of land so that the school would have room to expand on.
And that policy has seemed to continue with the school district because if you'll notice anywhere the school has
bought land for its site.
It's not just a site big enough for a school.
It's a site big enough for expansion or maybe a couple of schools.
And probably the best real estate developer in town is the school district.
My grandfather was also involved very much in community, well, in his business, homeowner drilling.
At that time, it was McMaster and Palmer, a water watch company.
He had gone in business with his brother-in-law, Clyde McMaster.
It seems that my grandfather, because of his father, knew a little bit about digging water bottles.
Basically, it was originally, it was he and Doug, and then he got to thinking,

They were grinding the sugar cane, which he had a sugar cane field, and they'd take, the grinder would be in the middle, they'd have a pole go out, they'd have a horse, and the horse would walk around and around and around.
He got to thinking, well, if I stick a shovel type device or something in the middle and let the pole go around and around and around, I can dig a hole.
So he started doing that.
I met my grandmother.
They got married and got to talking to his brother-in-law.
And his brother-in-law said, well, I got an engine.
Why don't you use my engine and your little turning device there?
And they started a water bottle business.
And my grandfather was also, with respect to the farming business, Pasadena, in the mid-'20s, decided that when they harvested the crop,
put it on the railroad cars and shipped them out of town.
They had to go into Houston and deposit the bill of ladings with the banks there in order to get paid.
And he and some of the other businessmen in the town said, well, gee, we ought to do that here in Pasadena.
Why should we have to go to Houston?
Well, the same idea occurred to some Houston people.
They said, well, let's open up a branch in Pasadena.
So on the same day in 1919, two banks opened.
One owned by a group of Houston people, and one owned and parked by my grandfather.
Two years later, the Pasadena bank
took over the Houston Bank, and that's still the largest bank in town, first passing the state bank.
My grandfather served on the board of directors of that bank for some, I have to check, but I think about 34 years.
And now my father has taken its place.
My uncle also, my master also served on the board of directors of that bank for many, many years.
My grandfathers also
involved in the civic affairs in the community.
He was an early member of the Pasadena Rotary Club.
It's a business service club in the community.
It is still the prima donna club.
It's where all the business can be once a week.
He was an active member of that, held several offices in it.
And one of the big things with him is he had a perfect attendance record.
And he had a perfect attendance record.
My father's now in it.
He's been in it 16 years, and he's got perfect attendance, and I've been in it two years now, and I've got perfect attendance.
Let's see, there was one other area that I was going to mention.
Oh, the churches.
My grandfather was involved in the churches.

As I mentioned earlier, my great-grandfather helped found First Baptist Church and my grandfather was raised in that church and felt very strong about it and continued to serve in many leadership as well as teaching positions in the church.
The other area of involvement with my grandfather would naturally be the business that he had in the community.
and I feel that it had an impact upon the community and helping it in its growth.
What impact did the Pomeroy business have on the community?
Now you're going to nail me to the wall here, okay?
Pomeroy started out first with the dairy business and then the farming business.
And back in those days, everybody would trade off and help each other.
In fact, I have my grandfather's book where he's listed today.
I worked three hours for Parks, and then a little later, ODC Parks came and worked three hours for us.
So he employed as well as helped other people.
As he got into the water well business, first, they naturally were drilling wells in the area for the farmers so that they would not have to

bring their wagons with the barrels on it down to up Main Street here to right across the street where the artesian well was until they got to take it back and try to put it on their berries and whatever.
But he drilled water in their field.
So he helped them not only improve their agricultural, but also to expand so that the community began to grow because water was available at different places.
We had a major strawberry
growing company from Houston that came to pass in.
It had something like 58 acres of berries under cultivation, and Tom Moore drilled the well for them.
As the ship channel industries came in here, they required water.
And Tom Moore's had drilled water wells for, man, I guess I have to say, everyone.
I can't think of one.
Michelle came.
They drilled three of them for the first year because they knew they needed that amount of water.
The Pomeroy's provided that critical element of water.
Because if you look historically at how towns are developed, it's always a long walk.
Towns always need water.
So the Pomeroy's, if the river wasn't there, then the Pomeroy's would provide the water for them.
They eventually wound up providing water for most of Houston.
And like they got with the railroads, the railroads would put the drilling rig on the flat car.
They'd go down 50 miles, and they'd unload.
The Pomeroy's drilled a well.
back of the railroad, go down 50 miles, and drop it off.
Because these were steam locomotives and they needed water.
So they provided water every 50 miles for the locomotives to stop and replace themselves.
I know the last count that we had was something over 2,000 water wells.
We drilled water wells specifically for the concrete companies that built the Astrodome.
That was our last major contribution.
But Rice Hotel, Warwick Hotel, Travis, Travis,
hotel, all those old hotels.
We drilled them apart.

Dad's fond of saying that when John Glenn went up and came back and his capsule was on display, went up into space, and his capsule was on display in Houston, they were on one corner and Pomeroy was down on the other corner reworking a water well through a manhole.
The water well was in the basement, so they parked on the street and took the manhole and they were reworking it.
And he'd say, the line would start at the capsule, and he would come by the water well rig and say, what are you doing?
What are you doing?
We provided a lot of water.
Also, well, I mentioned the early water well system.
The Pasadena needed a water well system.
The Conway was built a water well system.
We were the first ones in the Pasadena to have a bath tank, and we still have that bath tank.
I was talking to an early settler once, and he said, yes, if you wanted to tie onto the Conway water system, they didn't have a lot of valves.
So what you did, you took your hacksaw, and you got your pipe, and you went out there and started sawing.
The line was under pressure, so water started going everywhere, and you'd keep sawing, and you'd pull the pipe, and you'd do your joints, and you'd stick them back together.
I hope you didn't drown in the process.
But they also hired many, many people on those jobs.
During the summer, they'd have as many as 30 or 40 people employed.
And invariably, it would be schoolteachers, because the bombers were very close to the school, like the coaches and the woodshop teachers.
And any male teacher, they didn't, they didn't hire females.
Nothing prejudiced, it's just women didn't want to get that dirty or work that hard.
And there's one of the stories of Carol Teague, who's down on the State Board of Education.
He was a woodshop teacher, and his wife was expecting a child, and he was the only short on funds.
My grandfather found out about it, and he says, well, Carol, you know, we've got these jobs, why don't you come and work for us?
So Carol worked, I believe it was,
72 hours straight or something.
I forget exactly how the story goes.
But anyway, he made enough money, finished the job, went back home, his wife had the baby, and he could pay cash for it.
So there's a lot of little stories like that with the Palmeiras.
You talk to any old Tigers and they say, well, yeah, I used to work for the Palmeiras one summer.
It was amazing.
They probably hired a couple thousand people in the course of their history.
What was your grandfather's influence on the people in Pasadena?
Well, we covered some of that above.
I would say probably the thing most people remember him about was he was a peacemaker.
I had never really realized this until I went to his funeral.
And the preacher was out there talking about Brother John.
Everybody called him Brother John.
And he said when Brother John saw things were getting a little out of hand, he'd always put his hand up and sort of wave it and say, just take it easy.
And I remember that.
I never really thought about it.
And there were times when, like, the school wanted to, pardon me, the church wanted to expand.
They wanted to buy the land behind it.
And the people behind them just wouldn't sell.
They'd always send for the job.
And he just had a way of talking to people.
People had confidence in him.
And they'd work out some sort of compromise.
When the bank wanted to expand space and buy a new site, they couldn't work out a deal.
After about a year, they'd send for the job.
And he'd go work it out.
He was always long on advice.
He was a slow, deliberate, kind person.
He was extremely religious.
He was a living example of what he talked about.
So often you get upset about people in religion that make all these things about being religious, and they go out and catch them doing things that you say, well, you know, he's not living.
My grandfather lived an example.
He was involved with the church, as I had mentioned earlier, with his father that he served, first Baptist church, okay?
Got to one point where there was a rift in the church.
And he said, well, you know, I'm still going to church, and I don't like this church.
So a group of them went across the street and started another church.
It was Memorial Baptist Church, and it's still here.
After several years, the old group started making up.
So they came back in to First Baptist Church and they taught the preacher with them.
This is about 1940.
A preacher, John Morgan.
He was there, I think, until 1965.
Okay, about 58 or so, they got, the church decided that the town had moved beyond them, so they wanted to move out.
And they asked Brother John what he thought.
He said, I think that's an excellent suggestion, but I'm used to walking one block just
to the First Baptist Church.
So if you all move on out there, we'll start a new Baptist Church.
So South Main Baptist Church was started.
So he had, again, three churches in the community.
He served in leadership and all of those.
He was a school teacher for the men's class probably 20 years.
Same thing for my grandmother.
She was very much involved.
She taught many, many years in that church.
The, another, besides being the peacemaker, also many people came to my grandfather for financial advice.
He was a very hard worker.
He had a reputation of trying to be fair on any deal.
And when people had monetary questions, they would come and ask him, and he would give him, I know Grant Sexton, the photographer at the time.
I think he tells me the story every time I see him.
Your grandfather told you that?
You just own this man right here, and we'll be security forever.
So.
How have the lifestyles of people in Pasadena changed since the day of your grandfather?
Tremendous.
My grandfather came here in 1901.
He came in a wagon.
I have in one of his diaries, in the intro, about 1902,
where he's out on the farm there, and he sees a car come down, 225, in the port road.
And he noted the second car he'd ever seen in his life.
By the time of his death, 1981, we were walking in the noon.
So technologically, he saw a tremendous amount of change.
From a community standpoint, when he came, there was no religious community.
There is a tremendous religious community in the town now.
There was an unincorporated school with a one room, about 12 students.
And this is not only just Pasadena, it was the greater Pasadena area.
They were pulling them in from Deepwater and from South Houston and on over towards where Arco is now.
So they came from everywhere.
He saw the religion and the education of the community change.
It was a high priority, as the churches were.
So he had his guiding hand in the development of the school district.
And I think it's shown that the community is still very strong in education.
The social lifestyle of the community at that time was very much tied around the churches.
And it was you went to church Sunday morning, and then Sunday afternoon, you had a church event.
And that's where everybody got together, the Baptists and the Methodists.
And they would have sometimes competitions against each other.
There would be sack races and horseshoe pitching and all of those types of things.
But it was a very slow life.
I recall from him.
He got up.
His diaries reflect that he would get up in the morning, and he would hoe, and then he would go
work for someone else, and then the preacher would come over and forget where he'd ever been.
It was very, almost a humble existence, because on his birthday, his entry, after a whole day worth of activities, he said, and it was my birthday.
And that was the end of it.
There was no big, great celebrations.
There was no industry.
The workers that worked in agriculture
If you owned the property, you exchanged with each other your time.
If you were a worker, a picker, for instance, or a cultivator that came in, you got paid at the end of the season.
When the thing was harvested, it turned into money, then you got paid.
Along the way, you would receive some tokens.
Tokens were redeemable in local stores, so you could get your groceries.
Or the local merchants would just carry you.
And they knew you worked for John,
The park's over here, so they just wrote your name down in the ledger book.
And when you got through, you came in and you paid your bill.
One of the saddest things to me is when I returned from college in the 60s and found the front door of my family's house locked.
Because when I left in 59, nobody locked the door so fast.
There was no problem.
It was a very honorable community.
Everybody knew everybody.
There might be one or two rotten people in town, but they knew not to bother anybody.
They'd go out, they'd get drunk, and they'd go raise a little hell.
But that was it.
Industry came in, starting in 1917, 1918.
late 30s is when it really started growing.
And the town started as six families, which grew very slowly up until the 30s.
There was like 2,500 people in Pasadena in the mid-30s, and just over and out, and just mushroomed.
You had people coming in that just needed rooms, and so they started building more.
At that point, you stayed with someone until the house became available.
Or maybe after about four or five years, you could afford to build your own.
Invariably, it was a two-room type structure.
Kitchen, living room combination with the bedroom.
And if you had your own, they slept in the bedroom.
And after a couple years, you saved up some money and you built another room.
The Parks House is notorious for that.
They started out as a two-room house, and they had a successful strawberry crop, and they built a kitchen off that.

another one they built two bedrooms upstairs and another one they built the dining room and the house is a whole progression of additions there were very few there wasn't a wealthy class in the community everybody had about the same amount of money nobody flashed it around everybody pitched in and the community has just grown and changed and has become
I went through a period there in the 50s and 60s of being your typical bedroom community.
One of the, I think, prime community.
In 1929, I passed into the corporation for the final time.
And they hired two policemen, two motorcycle policemen.
They passed me and got a reputation as being a speed track.
Well, I'm sure in 1929, there wasn't even a handful of vehicles.
But during World War II, we had one motorcycle cop, and that was his job, just buying tickets.
It's like when you went through passing, you expected to get a ticket, because you were going to get a ticket.

And I used to, I'm sure other people felt the same way, in the 50s, saying, well, the police department's really great on traffic, but if there is a crime or something, they wouldn't know what to do with it.
Nowadays, we have a regional crime lab in Pasadena.
We have a very sophisticated police force.
We still have very strong traffic control.
You still get a ticket in Pasadena.
Yeah, let's see, lifestyles.
What other areas of lifestyles?
Religion, we've moved beyond Baptist and Methodist.
Somehow, Catholics slept in the community.
and then the Church of Christ, and the Lutheran, and the Episcopals.
We even have a Korean missionary church in town.
So other religions found their way in Pasadena.
Let's see, cultural activities.
Well, we progressed beyond the picnics, but we still have a ways to go.
That's another whole story someday I'll tell you.
How has your family influenced Pasadena's educational system?
Ah, education.

Well, besides being on the school board, both my great-grandfather and my grandfather, which were the early formative days, and they set the tenor of where we are today, I feel, the Pomeroy's mirrored into a bunch of school teachers.
So we were, I think we got some influence in that direction.
Clyde McMaster lost two of his wives to death.
And when he married Clayton McMaster, the wife that survived him, she was a schoolteacher.
And I forgot to mention, Clyde was also on the school board.
Let's see.
Clyde McMaster was on the school board.
John Pomeroy was on the school board.
16 years.
Payson Pomeroy was on the school board and Ben Williams was on the school board.
Lois Williams became Lois Pomeroy.
Fleeta Matthews became Fleeta McMasters.
Irma McMasters became Irma Williams.
And I'm sure we have another school teacher, too, in there.
Lois Pomoy was in charge of teacher training in the elementary levels for about 10, 15 years.

And she was responsible for, I don't know if it was a school program or her own program, but each year she would have her grandfather come in to the assembled elementary school and give them a lecture on Pasadena's history.
Oh, yes, I forgot to mention that one of the elementary schools in town is Pomeroy Elementary School, named for my great-grandfather's grandfather.
It's always an amazement to me to have someone say, oh, yes, my child graduated from Pomeroy Elementary.
Gee.
Most of Pasadena's growth has been over the last 30 years.
What impact has your family had in contributing to Pasadena's progress during this period?

You know, I have to confess that the Pomeroy impact was in the earlier days, in the formative stage, the setting up of the basic foundations for the community, the basic institutions, and they had a tremendous impact.
Although there weren't near as many people, they were extremely visible in participating in what they did.
In the last 30 years or so, one of the things I have to relate to you is sort of an agreement my grandfather had.
When he married my grandmother in 1811 and inherited a brother-in-law, Clyde McMaster,
They decided they were going into business together, one of the businesses I mentioned earlier.
John was a farm boy type thing.
He was, as I said, sort of slow, easy, and he was mechanically minded, and it was hard, hard work.
It had to be all of his luck.
Applied, had
had been around quite a bit.
He had participated in some of the drilling for oil wells.
And he had this engine, and he had worked with farmers on rice farms in a pretty good area around the state.
And he was sort of a wheeler-dealer-mover type guy.
And so my grandfather says, I'll tell you what, Clyde.
He said, I'll keep working with the water well business, and I'll keep the money coming in.
And why don't you take care of the community obligations for us?
I've got my church.
And at the time, he had the school board.
He did a little school board in there.
He said, you just take care of the other things.
So Clyde McMaster sort of took over the homeroom responsibility for community involvement.
Clyde was mayor of Pasadena 1931 to 1939.
There was only one other mayor that was in office for eight years.
That was Delbert Atkinson.
That followed, immediately followed him.
Clyde was there when the community made a radical change in the 30s from the farming warring community into what is now an industrial community.
So he was part of that driving force that pulled us sort of out of the dark ages, if you will.
Clyde was also a charter member of the Rotary Club.
He got my grandfather to participate because he thought it was important that we do that.
But Clyde was the type of person that says, well, what we need to do is get the businessmen together.
Grandfather...
The business had grown beyond the community, probably within the last 30 years or so.
It took him out of town.
And he was not in town all that much.
Continued to hire from the local community.
Talked very good about that.
Continued to influence the churches, as I mentioned earlier.
But in the school board, up until 19...
When was that?
Well, I had... Up into the, oh, 1934.
Then you get into the 40s and on, and he's off doing his business as he's left it to Clyde and also my uncle, Everett Williams, one of the Williams family I mentioned earlier.
He was involved in city council.
He was the water commissioner in town.
He was also chief of the volunteer fire department for a period of time and a lifelong member of the volunteer fire department.
Not until the last...
I'd say five years or so that we got re-involved in the community.
And most of that involvement has been through myself.
I had been away for a period of time.
I'd lived in Ohio and I'd been off to college and all that.
When I came back to the community, my grandfather had retired and my father had the business.

My great-grandfather Clyde, I mean, my great-uncle Clyde McMaster had died also, so it wasn't that many of the Pomeranians left, and the rest of them had moved out of the community into retirement areas.
So I felt some sort of responsibility.

One thing was preserving the history of the community, so I got back involved in the history of the community and became president of the Historic Society for a couple of years and continued to write their newsletter.
I got involved...
in the Chamber of Commerce.
I felt one of the things that the community needed was some statistical information for, or community information, really, beyond statistical.
You need statistical for businesses that want to come into the community or communities that want to grow.
And they said, well, what's the population of the community?
Where is the population?
What are the trends?
What's your employment level?
Economic scale and all of that.
So I got very involved in
pulling together that type of information to make it available.
Also, promotional materials about the community.
Not only, I call them promotional, but people coming into the community and saying, what is Pasadena?
What's the quality of life?
What's the religious atmosphere?
What's the school atmosphere?
Those types of things.
So we've tried to pull that together so that these people will know what Pasadena is.
And then the often overlooked area that you want to communicate with is the people within the community.
They live there.
They work there.
And quite often, they say, well, I don't really know what Pasadena is.
I didn't know that about Pasadena.
And so we're trying to, we're pulling together, we're promoting Pasadena to Pasadenas.
Some of us feel there's an image problem.
Well, we're trying to work on that.
We're trying to get the people of Pasadena first to feel good about Pasadena.
When we feel good about our community, then it radiates.
And other people know.
And that's half of the publicity promotion jobs want.
I got drafted into Rotary, as I mentioned earlier.
And there's been involved in quite a few things in promoting the community.
So Palm Roys are again shaping the direction of the community.
In your opinion, what are the reasons behind Pasadena's tremendous growth and change over the last several decades?
Well, let's put it
And let me give you sort of an overview.
The community was founded in 1895, 97 era.
It depends on where you want to draw the line in the beginning, okay?
In the 1890s, railroads were put into the era.
Up to that point, it was just ranching.
And with the railroads, there came a group of promoters that said, hey, let's open this up, sell some land.
The cities of La Porte,
Deer Park, Deepwater, Seabrook, Kima, Genoa, South Houston, and Pasadena all came into existence within about 10 years of each other.
Today, Pasadena is 125,000 people.
And if you combine the populations of all those other communities, you might get 60,000.
They all started out basically the same way.
Some of them had a little more advantages.
Pasadena was the only town that didn't have a hotel.
First thing a developer did was to build a hotel.
You'd run an ad in New York or Illinois or Indiana and have people come down to buy land.
The promised land, the sunbelt.
For that reason, they had it.
And they'd come and they'd stay in the hotel.
Well, Pasadena didn't have a hotel.
By 1910, 1920, La Porte had a couple thousand people.
Deer Park had a couple of hundred people, and Pasadena would have had less than a hundred.
But Pasadena, for some reason, eventually attracted more people.
It got rid of people from deep water and said, well, I think I'm going to go over to Pasadena.
I've got a couple of real cute stories on that.
And Pasadena just, perhaps with palm oil and water, was able to grow as an agricultural center.
And we grew more than any of the other cities.
We continued as an agricultural community on into the 30s.
Now, our character changed in the 30s.
The Houston Ship Channel, which was a dream of the people from Houston, and they had been working on it since pre-1900, started promoting it as a ship channel.
They dredged it out.
They got an oil company by the name of
Sinclair to come and build a place in 1917.
Forgotten.
Crown came the year before, Crown Refinery.
They had all this oil down in Spindletop, Goose Creek, and Baytown.
And the people in Houston says, well, gee, we ought to have a shipping port.
If we refine it here instead of sending it up to those Standard of Indiana and all that Sinclair people up there, we need it here.
So they started promoting Houston Ship Channel.
Well, that was going on in the background
Pasadena more or less ignored it.
That's on its northern boundary.
And it was looking south where all the farming was.
And we were shipping.
And that just sort of existed back there.
But in the 1930s, 1937, Champion Paper decided to open up a mill in Pasadena.
Because one of the major industries in Houston was a lumber.
Jesse Jones, who most everybody knows, was very big in the lumber business.
Champion decided to open up a mill.
When Champion opened, they hired several hundred people.
And what happened there was that it provided a choice to the labor market.
Labor market up to this point, when you worked, you worked until the end of the season, you got your pay.
But with the industry, you got paid every week.
And you had a job 52 weeks out of the year, 53, how many years there is.
So the choice was, okay, well, let's go to work for the industry.
The industry also needed more than the local market, so it started bringing people in.
As they brought people in, they needed houses.
Houses and people needed grocery stores and laundries and movie houses and city government.
So 37 became a major turn in the shift in Pasadena.
This was just the beginning of a just phenomenal growth in the community.
It came from 2000 in the first half.
of Pasadena's existence to now under 25,000 in the second half, basically equal periods of time.
But 37 was the beginning.
Although we didn't, the United States didn't enter into World War II until the 40s, the effect of the war was felt locally in Pasadena as early as 1938-39 because the U.S.
people and industry supported the war effort in Europe.
So we geared up the petroleum industry down here with the oil refining to provide petro for the allies.
We also worked on chemicals with Sinclair Chemical Corporation, which is now
Petrotex, well, Arco is the refining side of Petrotex.
It's the chemical side of the deal.
Goodyear Rubber, all of these started about that period of time.
Houston Shipbuilding and Brown Brothers Shipbuilding started at that time, and they employed thousands of people.

So all of a sudden this community that had supported some farms and one or two small refineries, then a paper mill with about 500 people, is now an employment center for thousands and thousands of people.
So the communities just started growing in leaps and bounds.
To give you an example, in 1940, the population of Pasadena was 3,400.
It had grown seven times by 1950 to 22,000.
It grew two and a half times during the 50s to 58,000 in the 60s and continued to grow at the rate of about 3,000 a year on up through the 1980s.
Now, one of the perennial questions I have is, why Pasadena?
I mentioned Deepwater, Deer Park, the port, South Houston, all of those communities.
What happened there?
Well, Deer Park was all but abandoned when Shell came in in the late 30s.
And so they had to start from scratch as far as a community.
It was strictly a veteran community associated with Shell.
The port's orientation was supposedly to shipping.
Because it was the port of opportunity.
That's what the port was supposed to be.
But they had developed over the years Sylvan Beach.
So it became the playground, the recreation community.
And everything was related to that.
They didn't take, they weren't in a position to take advantage of what's happening during World War II.
South Houston is rail-oriented.
It's not port-oriented.
So they were not
directly able to take care, to take advantage of the industry.
However, the first aviation in the area was in South Houston.
They had the first airplane manufacturing facility in Harris County that I'm aware of.
And Allentown Airport space was built because of that during World War I.
Okay?
And then reactivated in World War II.
We had the first, the largest bomber school in the nation or something during World War II out of Delaware.
But those didn't provide a strong
economic base, as did the industry.
Again, the shipbuilding stuff, the chemical and petroleum directly related to Pasadena.
And Pasadena was in place, now had government, it had the basic services, and we just took advantage of what was there.
We attracted a couple of influential, that is, dynamic people into the community.
And they took the lead as far as providing development.
Delbert Atkinson was one of those people, as was Herbert Tarter, Anderson.
They formed the real estate development firm of Tarter, Atkinson, and Anderson.
And all of the stuff along Tarter Street, which was renamed in Herbert Tarter's honor, was all a development.
They knew how to work the government programs.
They got the funding for the houses.
And so they were throwing up houses as fast as you could possibly do it.
But the industry and the housing, we were able to capture the people.
Our growth has continued to track that at the Houston Ship Channel.
As it has diversified and there's more chemical companies and the shipping has increased, we've been able to take advantage of that.
And we've continued the initial momentum.
Strong with the churches, strong with the schools, so we're a strong family community.
We had a tremendous number, in fact, probably the basis for our growth during this period, people that came out of East Texas.
They were coming to Pasadena to make money in the industry, and then they were going back to East Texas.
They never made it back to East Texas.
They're still here.
They still keep saying, I'm going to go back to East Texas.
A lot of them have retired, back to East Texas, and said, well, my friends are back in Pasadena.
So they moved back to Pasadena.
So we've continued that.
We were
also able to take advantage of what happened down in Clear Lake with NASA and the stuff that was developing down there.
When Exxon was developing Clear Lake, it was developed as an executive-type town.
A lot of the non-managerial workers were located in Pasadena because the housing was cheaper.
It had a good school system and the other things that we mentioned before.
So we've been able to take advantage of that.
In the last 10 years, we've got a new type of growth going on in the community.
It's not so much in numbers as it is in quality, quality of life in the community.
Up until the late 50s, Pasadena sort of viewed itself as a bedroom community.
If you wanted anything in the way of culture, entertainment, all those types of things, you went to Houston.
If you wanted a good place to eat, you went to Houston.
This was a local community with basic services.
What with the oil crisis in the 70s, it got expensive to get to Houston for number one.
The city was growing so fast that the road system was not that adequate, so it began to take longer to get into Houston.
Some of the racial problems they had in Houston,
People said, well, I think I just want to stay in my own community.
So in the last 10 years, five years, three years, we've started saying, hey, we need to provide some of those things in our own community ourselves.
And so we've got this new form of growth.
And as we provide those things, it begins to attract more in the way of professional services, more attorneys, accountants, doctors, the medical profession in this community in the last
10 years is phenomenal.
The quality change that we've gotten.
The hospitals.
I wouldn't have come to passing a hospital 10 years ago or five years ago.
But now we've got some outstanding things.
We've got some equipment that are second only to the Texas Medical Center.
Better than any place else in the world.
We're tied to the Texas Medical Center with the emergency helicopter service.
So if they can't handle it here, they can get you into Houston.
We talked about religion.
Religion, as always, had an important role in Pasadena.
Was your family involved in Pasadena's religious community?
Well, I think we beat that horse to death.
We've covered that before.
I hate to repeat a lot of the things that I've said in the past, but in a nutshell, yes, I believe we have.
religion is a very strong thing.
It continues to be a very strong thing.
It has shaped the communities in some ways positive, some ways negative.
We don't have all the denominational beliefs in the community.
I don't know if it's because the Protestants have just spread their elbows and said, no, this is our territory, or what it's been.
I know the Catholics tease a little bit about
having to fight their way into the community.
Let me just wrap that up by saying that religion has played a significant role in the community.
It does today.
The religious community is very much involved.
It's an outreach type religion.
It's not a, you know, you just come to us on Sundays type thing.
It caters to the needs of all the people.
It's going out aggressively after specialty groups, battered wives and alcoholism.
The Catholic group put together and all the other religious communities supported this Pasadena family time.
which is the objective there is to bring the family a little closer together.
Some of their specific programs is like on a certain night, you pledge that you will spend the evening with your family and family activities.
The restaurants and towns have given discounts.
If you bring your family in on like Thursday night, you get 10% off and those types of things.
So, you know, religion is a very dominant force in the community.
You know, one of those little...
sort of funny type things you like to throw in from time to time.
I hope it doesn't ruffle anybody's feathers.
But one of the contributions that religion has made to the community, it's a strange partnership with Sherwood Pryor, who owns the Gillies.
It seems that Pasadena at one point was sort of the late bloomer in the prohibition era.
Although the United States had prohibition back in the 20s and came out of that, the Baptists decided
back in the late 40s that, gee, we ought to have prohibition in Pasadena.
And so they got together, organized a group, and voted Pasadena dry.
So you couldn't buy alcohol or serve alcohol and say, well, it's Pasadena.

Election came back up in the 50s, and I don't know if this necessarily is true, but I've heard that the bootleggers and the bear joints around the outside of the city provided money to the Baptists to underwrite the campaign to continue to keep Pasadena dry.
so the competition would stay out of the area.
Since then, Pasadena has incorporated a lot of areas, and everybody's afraid to bring the issue up.
So the new areas, you can have outfall.
They're wet.
The old areas of Pasadena, you can't have outfall.
And everybody's afraid to bring the issue up, afraid it'll go one way or the other, so we have a divided city.
What was the fabulous 50s like for the Pomeroy's in Pasadena?
Well, since I was a teenager in the fabulous 50s, it was fabulous.
Fabulous 50s for Pasadena was a breaking out of the old downtown area.
In the early 50s, well, the commercial district of Pasadena centered around 225 and parallel street would be Shaw, just north of that, and ran from Shaver,
to Main Street, about two, three blocks.
And that was, everything was within that area.
City Hall, all the commercial establishments.
With the 40s, we had had, you know, Woolworth came into town, and we had dress shops, and specialty clothes shops, and movie houses, and, you know, we were high cotton there.
In the 50s, with the population, as I mentioned earlier, now up to 22,000, we ran out of room.
We started growing south.
All of the old strawberry farms became subdivisions.
And you look at the subdivision names, and you can see who owned land there.
There's McMaster and Pomeroy subdivision.
There's a Park subdivision one, Park subdivision two, Park subdivision three.
There's a Parker subdivision.
All of the old names, also on the streets.
But we had the first commercial step out, really.
Sears, well, a guy by the name of John Campbell came to Pasadena.
And he built the Campbell Centers.
Now the Campbell Centers were down in Southmoor.
Southmoor was just probably gravel when he started it, probably blacktop when he finished it.
Everybody thought he was crazy because you couldn't even see Southmoor from Pasadena.
But he started that out there.
There were a few subdivision houses out there.
Carter and Atkinson were accommodating.
Campbell built a few homes of his own, so they started growing out there.
He got Sears to come out to his shaver and south wall.
And all of a sudden, you know, the downtown was moving away.
Businessmen downtown made a mistake.
Or the government.
I'm not sure.
I don't know exactly who did it.
They decided we're going to raise some revenue.
We're going to put in parking meters.
So they put in parking meters downtown.
And, of course, everybody just complained about putting pennies in a parking meter.
There were pennies there.
So when Campbell built his thing, advertising, free parking, the merchants downtown said, wait a minute, so there was, like on Thursdays you could park downtown free.
But it was a losing battle because the handwriting was on the wall.
I first passed it in the state bank, realized that, and moved out to Southmore and Carter in the early, I think 1960s when they opened up out there.
City Hall opened up out there at the same time.
hospitals.
The two downtown hospitals closed and new ones opened up.
First Baptist Church moved from its original location in the old downtown area into the new neighborhoods.
So we had a tremendous shift going on there.
Unfortunately, there was a guy by the name of Corrigan, Leo Corrigan from
that came into Pasadena in the late 40s and said, boy, I'm going to build me a super shopping center.
And we built it in the old downtown area.
And by the mid-50s, everybody was leaving downtown.
But it was great for me because, boy, there was a movie theater right down the street.
I'd ride my bicycle down here to the Saturday matinee, go in at 9 o'clock and come out at 4 in the afternoon.
I used to pick blackberries there a couple years earlier.
And the drive-ins came to town, you know, the drive-in restaurants where you would go to Trainers.
You may not even remember Trainers.
Trainers is now where 7-Eleven is over there by the port, 225.
That was a drive-in.
Down at the other end of town was the Corat.
And, you know, in the 50s, we'd get in our cars and we'd drive down to the Trainers and we'd drive around to see if we knew anybody.
And then we'd drive down to the other end to see if we knew anybody, try picking up somebody in between.
That was the day of American Band Standing.
That was probably, that was the decade I learned to dance.
We had, although the band just don't give a dance, even the men just do, okay?
But that's all right.
It's not Sunday, you know, you do what you want.
And learned to dance, teen canteen type thing.
That was back in my courting days.
The Hugh Pastino Rodeo, okay, it starts back in the 50s.
Mm-hmm.
And I forgot to mention that the biggest recreational activity in town was the Pasadena Miniature Golf Course, which my parents built.
And I was the manager when I was nine years old, or something like that, 11 years old.
I was the manager.
Yeah, I'd babysit the cash register, drink the Cokes, and eat the peanuts and snow cone.
But there was nothing else in town, really.
Everybody came over and played miniature golf course.
It was a lot of fun, playing miniature golf at the golf course.
There we go.

that was the beginning of the era just a second there was one other i have to do have to digress there was another activity in town which was the skating skating rink skating pasting it was terrific thoroughly enjoyed it between the captain skating rink miniature golf course school parades and all those types of things i had a very full life thoroughly until i had a horse too who didn't uh 50s were also
From a city government standpoint, Pasadena was getting some strain on the city government.
The town was growing very fast.
We had a part-time city government.
We had a part-time mayor, we had a part-time councilman.
I think the councilman got like $50 a week and the mayor got $150 a month, and the mayor got $150.
The city was growing, we're talking pushing 50,000 people,
9,000 people by the time we got to the end of the 50s.
And it began to show in the government because some of these people were putting in quite a bit of time and not getting any more compensation.
So there was some scandals going on in government.
They were taking a little money on the side.
They were using city employees to fix up certain things of theirs.
And it was only into the early 60s that we were having left with a couple of mayors that were at least reviewed for indictment.
And finally, the community realized that, gee, we do need some full-time
city officials.

And so we changed the city charter and we went through some sort of change in that period of time where the mayor became a full-time job and they could afford to pay at that time $20,000, $25,000, which was good money.
So we could attract some people.
City councilmen still continue to get small funds.
It's viewed as a part-time job, but they still spend a lot of time.
But we had a psychological change in our government format.
